This country has a long tradition of recognizing its military heroes - or at least some of them.
Now a new exhibition in San Francisco is paying tribute to a class of decorated vets who haven't received a lot of recognition - gays.
As NPR's John McChesney reports, the exhibition is called Out Ranks.
The first thing you see when you walk in the door of the exhibit is a slightly worn blue Air Force jacket, with staff sergeant stripes on the sleeve.
It belonged to Leonard Matlovich.
Leonard Matlovich came out as a gay man in the Air Force in 1975.
And he was the first person to legally challenge the ban on gays in the military.
Steve Estes interviewed 50 gay veterans for his book ""Ask and Tell."" His book was the inspiration for this exhibit.
Behind the jacket is a Time magazine cover with a photo of Matlovich.
He came out just as the war in Vietnam was ending and at a time when no one talked about gays in the military.
His medals are on display here as well.
He served a couple of tours in Vietnam.
He had been wounded.
He got a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star.
In every sense of the word, he was a hero.
But when he came out, the military kicked him out.
Matlovich became the poster boy for gays in the military and later won a civil suit against the Air Force.
Estes leads me over to another exhibit.
One of my favorite artifacts in the exhibit is this bulletproof Bible.
It's a Bible but as you can see, it's sheathed in steel on the front and the back.
And Michael Job, who lives here in San Francisco and who served in Vietnam, his mom gave it to him when he was drafted.
Job, who lives in San Francisco in an apartment adorned with a peace symbol, says he volunteered for the draft because a fellow teacher asked him if he was a homosexual.
He says it scared him to death.
And I went in the military because I had it wired that if you go in the military it proves you aren't gay.
Job says he would come back from leave with staged pictures of him with women to show to his buddies.
He was with the 101st Airborne in the northern part of Vietnam.
He was part of a machine gun team, and says they faced some tough combat.
